This is great in terms of rhyming, and I like the story of the poem. To improve it visually, maybe you could structure it less like a block of text by putting each line underneath the previous (though you might have already tried to do this, I can see you've capitalised each phrase?). Another way to bring it together a bit more would be to even up the number of syllables in each phrase - when you read out loud the last two lines they seem to have more syllables crammed in when compared to the others, which upsets the rhythm of the piece. I think the idea is interesting and original - thanks for posting.

I think notebooks (the paper ones) are much more convenient to carry around but my school tends to give out a lot of handouts which work alongside the notes you take in class, so I've been using ring binders this year. For uni though, I doubt they'll give printouts or anything so personally i think spiral-bound notebooks would be the best option. If you get ones which have those easy-rip dotted lines along the spines and holes already punched in them, then you can file your notes at the end of each section/term as well. Nicely bound notebooks tend to be on the pricey side, and unless you're able to take meticulous notes really quickly, it might feel like a bit of a waste to have messy notes in a nice notebook which you'll copy up neatly somewhere else later on. (although it's totally up to you!) Whiteboards are *fantastic*... I love using them, since they're great for all subjects (e.g. like you mentioned, brainstorming for humanities and doing calculations for sciences). i would make sure you have a good rubber, though, because the little bits of dry ink can be pretty annoying when they go everywhere. edit: [maybe the nice notebook thing's just me](http://www.reddit.com/r/GetStudying/comments/1ybwn9/a_simple_tip_to_improve_your_notetaking_during/)

Try focusing on where the exams can take you. You're aware that you can get better than your preliminary grades, since you've gotten better results before - all you have to do is study a bit. Try thinking for a moment about what you want to do with the good grades you'll get (what universities, careers etc) and then work back from there - if you have a clear goal, all you have to do is pick up your pen to start getting there.

When the itchiness is 100% distracting (like, you can't bear to sit still and write-itchiness) it might be an idea to switch to podcasts (or other audio stuff) on the topics you need to cover. It won't make the itchiness go away, but a direct sound stream from headphones might distract you from the itchiness a bit, while giving you that stream of info. You can also move round with your headphones in, if you're feeling restless.

people ask/give advice about studying/getting their academic life together, post useful links (e.g. recommended flashcard apps etc) and generally motivate each other to get studying/keep up the hard work. There are also accountability threads posted daily in which people write out their academic work to-do lists, which they cross stuff off of that they've completed. It's a really friendly subreddit - all criticism is constructive (I hope), so if you want to know about/ have some useful new study techniques or something, post away!

By necessary accommodations, do you mean extra tutoring sessions? If not, then getting extra one on one help from the teachers might be something to look into, especially if you're not on top of the class content. They don't necessarily have to teach you everything again, but you could maybe ask them to set aside 20 minutes during lunch, for example, to answer your questions (which you'll probably have more of, compared to other students). As for focus and commitment, I think this whole sub recommends the pomodoro method of study. You probably know it, but if not, have a look. I think it might work for you because you can set your work-burst time according to your preferences - what I do when I'm feeling restless is work in 20-minute bursts, which is short enough for me to keep my concentration, but just long enough to get a(n albeit small) chunk done.

UK A-level student here. In terms of content revision, since you're only a week away I would do practice question after practice question for the bulk of your studying. Read the revision cards/guides/books during spare moments, like during breakfast or on your commute etc. For essay based subjects exams, exam technique is almost as important as the content. I do English literature but I'm gonna assume the structure of the language exam is the same = 2 essay questions (correct me if I'm wrong). For each, make sure you know your assessment objectives - for Lit we have AO1 to AO4, and you need to have all of them in an essay to get good marks (If you don't know them, google them for your exam board). Also, make a list of key terms to include in your exam essays (in Literature it's best to always include words like semantic field and lexis and stuff when analysing a passage; I'm sure you have words like that in Language). PM me if you need any help setting up a short term revision timetable or something.

Hey, current year 12 repeater here. Ngl, I am in the exact same boat as you for some of my final exams, despite my parents forking up a ton to send me to private school to repeat the year, so obvs I'm regretting not working as hard as I could have for my exams yesterday and the day before. I've already made the mistakes, Op. Don't be me, seriously. In order to avoid being me - to put it bluntly - you should be working your arse off on those undone units right now... whoo if you are, if not then do so. You still have a few weeks, which may not seem like much, but if you put your absolute all in then you'll probably be able to scrape by and get the grades. Pm me if you want an accountability buddy or something. As for getting a job, there's not much longer until summer. What I would do would be to promise your parents that you'll get a job at the beginning of summer (make sure to actually do so) after you've submitted your work/ tests and stuff and earned those credits.

gt; If you don't have a job over the holidays then studying should be your new full time job. You don't have classes to worry about yet so set up your studying time in 2 hour stretches for each topic. Stop studying when your parents/social life finish their jobs, cause your work day is now over. This this this. work 9-5 days, and you'll still have time for a bit of a lie-in/long breakfast since you'll have no commute, and your evenings free for doing other stuff. gt; you should know what you have to do every hour of your day As stated, timetable every hour of this 9-5 day with the work you will get done. Create this timetable on Saturday morning for Sunday - Friday (maybe give yourself Friday nights to go out and stuff, if that's what you're into).

b) basically, to go from a value for displacement (x) to a value for velocity (v) you need to differentiate the equation for displacement because the acceleration isn't a constant value. So in this question x is given by x=t^2 -7t+12. To find v, differentiate the above. I'm guessing you don't know how to differentiate? If so, here's a simplified explanation you can use in answering your question. You take the power of t and multiply it with the number in front of the t, then subtract 1 from the original power. so T^2 will become 2t^1, or just 2t. You do the same with the next value: -7t. The t here is to the power of 1, so bring that in front and subtract 1 from the original power, and you should end up with -7t^0 , or just -7 as t^0 is 1. Then the last value, 12. since this value does not have a t behind it, we scrap it. So put them all together and you'll have dx/dt = 2t-7 then plug in t=0 into this differential: 2(0)-7 = -7ms^-1 I hope that helps.

maybe look into the UTokyo courses in English? PEAK courses, I think they were called. There are only two there, and they're pretty specific, but the Uni of Tokyo is more well-known overseas than others, so if you were to not like it there/ move back overseas for a job, chances are you'll have an easier time transferring/with job applications than if you were to have gotten a degree from a Japanese uni that has a good name in japan but is unknown overseas.
